Text:
Bible Lesson Planner creates complete Sunday school lessons in minutes.

Enter your Scripture and age group. Get a full lesson plan with activities, discussion questions, and printable materials.

"Your word is a lamp for my feet, a light on my path." - Psalm 119:105

Preschool Lesson Sample: Noah's Ark (Genesis 6-9)

Opening: Animal sounds game
Story: God keeps His promises (simplified for ages 2-4)
Activity: Animal matching pairs
Craft: Paper plate rainbow
Take-home: Coloring page with "God keeps His promises"

"I have set my rainbow in the clouds." - Genesis 9:13

Create preschool lessons at biblelessonplanner.com

#SundaySchoolCurriculum #ChildrensMinistry

Elementary Lesson Sample: The Good Samaritan (Luke 10:25-37)

Discussion Questions:
- Who are the "neighbors" in your life?
- Why did the priest and Levite walk past?
- How can you help someone this week?

Activity: Map out the road from Jerusalem to Jericho. Students draw where they can be a good neighbor in their community.

"Love your neighbor as yourself." - Mark 12:31

Create this lesson at biblelessonplanner.com

#BibleLesson #ChildrensMinistry

Middle School Lesson Sample: David and Goliath (1 Samuel 17)

Go deeper with 11-13 year olds:
- What "giants" do students face today?
- Why did David trust God when others doubted?
- Discussion: Faith vs. fear in real situations

Includes journaling prompts and small group questions.

"The Lord who rescued me from the paw of the lion and the paw of the bear will rescue me from this Philistine." - 1 Samuel 17:37

biblelessonplanner.com

High School Lesson Sample: James 1 (Trials and Temptation)

Designed for teenage discussion:
- What's the difference between trials and temptation?
- How do you respond when faith is tested?
- Real-world application scenarios

Includes: Video discussion guide, small group questions, personal reflection worksheet.

"Consider it pure joy whenever you face trials of many kinds, because the testing of your faith produces perseverance." - James 1:2-3

Bible Lesson Planner adjusts content for every age group:

Preschool (2-4): Simple stories, movement, crafts

Upper Elementary (8-10): Deeper questions, journaling
Middle School (11-13): Discussion-based, real-world application
High School (14-17): Theological depth, personal reflection

Sample discussion questions from Bible Lesson Planner:

For "The Prodigal Son" (Luke 15:11-32):
- Why did the younger son want to leave?
- How do you think the father felt waiting?
- Have you ever needed to say sorry and come back?
- Why was the older brother upset?

Age-appropriate questions generated for each lesson.

"But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and was filled with compassion." - Luke 15:20

biblelessonplanner.com
